Why Play Roulette with Bitcoin?

Most advantages of Bitcoin roulette come from the fact that you are using Bitcoin as your currency of choice, regardless of the game that you are playing. Have a look at this table below:

Pros

  • Playing with Bitcoins gives you a lot more privacy. If you have any experience with online casinos, you will know that most of them only ask for your e-mail and e-wallet address at cashout (unless you hit the jackpot, but you probably won't mind their KYC process in that case).
  • The speed of Bitcoin transactions is measured in minutes or even in seconds, whereas credit card transactions or wire transfer can take days.
  • There is no bank behind Bitcoin to charge you transaction fees. Your only expense is your fee to Bitcoin miners, which is negligible.
  • With Bitcoin came blockchain, and with blockchain came provably fair games. What this means is that you can look behind the scenes of a game to make sure that it is not rigged.
  • You can get much, much higher bonuses with Bitcoin - and this holds true for many cases. Take a look at first deposit bonus from Bitstarz casino: 100 € or 1 BTC.
  • You do not have to give anyone any bank or credit card information (or even your personal information), so all of your accounts remain safe.

Cons

  • Bitcoin price is always changing, which may affect how much money you actually have in your casino account and your winnings may be lower (or higher!) when you receive them, compared to when you requested your withdrawal.

Some people add another con to Bitcoin, stating that it is not as user-friendly as other payment methods, but in my experience it is no more complicated than having to deal with an online bank. I suppose that you have no problems with this particular notion either since you are here, reading this guide.

Live roulette by Zugi from 7Bit Casino

Live roulette games come in two different variants: with or without a dealer (croupier).

Games with a dealer are the classic option. The dealer runs the game, tells you when it’s time to place bets, when the time is up, he or she spins the roulette wheel, throws in the ball and tells you on which slot the ball landed. Of course, you also view the live feed of the roulette wheel.

Live games without the dealer are called automatic or auto roulette. The only difference here is that the roulette wheel is spun automatically and all timings and results are declared by a computer.

However, neither variant shows you the live feed of the game board where the bets are placed, so you cannot see the bets from other players unless you ask them directly.

Roulette Rules and Layout

A roulette game consists of a game board where you place bets, a roulette wheel with a ball, and your casino chips.

The roulette wheel has 36 numbers and a zero (0). For each turn the roulette wheel is spun one way and the ball the other way. The aim of the game is to guess in which ball pocket the ball will land once the wheel stops spinning.

Ball pockets on the wheel alternate between red and black – except for zero, which is green.

Roulette table by Betsoft from mBit Casino

You bet by placing chips onto the board which has numbers from 0 to 36. Each number has a colored field that corresponds to the color of that number on the roulette wheel. With a single chip you can bet on a single number, on two, three, four, five or six numbers, or on a special category of numbers.

Placing a chip on 2 numbers is called a split bet (see the chip on 7 and 10 in the image above).

Betting one chip on 3 numbers is possible for 0, 1, 2 and 0, 2, 3. You can do this by placing the chip on the adjacent corners of the numbers or on any 3 numbers in the same row (this is also called a street bet – see the chip on the outer edge of number 24).

To bet on 4 numbers, place a chip on all four adjacent corners as shown in the image above (also called a corner bet). Placing a chip on the line between 0 and other numbers on the outer edge of the board allows you to bet on 0, 1, 2 and 3 at the same time (this is also called a top line bet – see the chip on the corner of number 1). American version of roulette allows you to make the same kind of bet on 5 numbers because there are 2 zeros, but more on that later.

To bet on 6 numbers, a chip can be placed on the outer two adjacent corners of two numbers (also called a six line bet – see the chip on numbers 30 and 33).

Outside Bets

Additional fields around the numbers, also called ‘outside bets,’ allow you to make other, safer bets, because you bet on a third or on half of all numbers – except for 0. These bets are:

  • 1st, 2nd or 3rd 12: Bet on all numbers on the 1st (1-12), 2nd (13-24) or 3rd (25-36) part of the board.
  • 1 to 18 or 19 to 36: Bet on all numbers on the 1st or second half of the board.
  • Even/odd: Bet on all even or all odd numbers.
  • Red/black: Bet on all numbers with a red or black field.
  • 2 to 1: Bet on all numbers in the 1st, 2nd or 3rd column of the board.

All these bets also have different probabilities to win, and along with this come different payouts if you win. I explain roulette betting odds and payouts a few scrolls down.

European, American and French Bitcoin Roulette

Roulette comes in 3 different types: European, American and French. You can find hundreds of other roulette variants that originate from these three or a mixture of these three types, but I cover those later in other roulette types and adaptations.

European, American and French roulette vary in board and wheel appearance, and consequently also in odds and in the way the game is played.

The difference between European, American and French roulette table

The most common type is European roulette. If the name or the thumbnail image of a casino’s roulette game do not specifically state the type, you can be 90 % sure that the game in question is European roulette.

Board

game board is in French

‘La Partage’ and ‘en Prison’ Rules

French roulette has 2 additional rules called ‘La Partage’ (the divide) and ‘En Prison’ (in prison). They both apply only to even money bets. In the first case you get half of your money back if the wheel spins zero. In the second case your bet gets ‘frozen’ in case of a zero, and you get all your money back if you win the next spin with the frozen bet. Both cases cut the house edge in half, to 1.35 %.

I explain what these additional rules do to your odds 3 chapters down in roulette betting odds, payouts and options.

The Racetrack

The roulette racetrack is an additional part of the betting board which can be found in French and sometimes in European roulette.

Roulette racetrack from a game by WorldMatch from 24K Casino

Roulette racetrack from a game by WorldMatch from 24K Casino
It is shaped as a loop, resembling a racetrack, hence the name. The numbers are the same as on the roulette wheel. The center of the loop has 4 (in some cases 5) fields representing all possible fixed call bets on the racetrack. 2 additional variable call bets do not have their own field because the numbers included depend on your choice.

English Bet Name: neighbors of zero

Bet Type: fixed call bet
Includes Numbers: 0, 2, 3, 4, 7, 12, 15, 18, 19, 21, 22, 25, 26, 28, 29, 32, 35
Odds: 45.9 %

English Bet Name: third of the wheel

Bet Type: fixed call bet
Includes Numbers: 5, 8, 10, 11, 13, 16, 23, 24, 27, 30, 33, 36
Odds: 32.4 %

English Bet Name: orphans

Bet Type: fixed call bet
Includes Numbers: 1, 6, 9, 14, 17, 20, 31, 34
Odds: 21.6 %

English Bet Name: zero game

Bet Type: fixed call bet
Includes Numbers: 0, 3, 12, 15, 26, 32, 35
Odds: 18.9 %

English Bet Name: neighbours

Bet Type: variable call bet
Includes Numbers: a number of your choice + 2 numbers on the right and 2 on the left, 5 in total
Odds: 13.5 %

English Bet Name: final

Bet Type: variable call bet
Includes Numbers: a number of your choice + all numbers with the same final digit (example: 16 + 6, 26, 36)
Odds: 10.8 % for numbers with 0-6 as the final digit and 8.1 % for numbers with 7-9 as the final digit

Roulette Betting Odds, Payouts and Options

Different roulette types have different odds, and different bets have different odds of winning. Payouts go hand in hand with betting odds – the lower the odds, the higher the payout.

In the table below I gathered all possible bets on all possible roulette types, along with odds and payouts.

Before you dive in, let me just explain how I write the numbers:

  • probabilities or odds: 1:35 is the same as 34 to 1 or 1/35 ≈ 0.0286 ≈ 2.9 %, the numbers in the table represent the probability of winning
  • payouts: 35:1 will give you 35 times your bet plus your original bet back (example: if you bet $1, you win $35 and end up with $36)

I show you how you can calculate your own probabilities and outcomes at the end if this is something that you struggle with.

1:37 ≈ 2.7 %

How to Calculate Probabilities

‘La Partage’ and ‘En Prison’ rules of the French roulette are the only two outcomes that were not represented in the table above. You will see why in a minute.

I am going to use the ‘En Prison’ rule as an example to show you how you can calculate your own winning and losing odds. The calculation procedure is basically always the same, so you can apply it to other kinds of bets.

First, let’s do an overview of some basics. Before you start crunching numbers, figure out how many possible results there are for each turn or each bet that you make. Since there are 37 slots on the roulette wheel and the ball can only land inside one slot after each spin, you have 37 different possible outcomes.

Now to calculate probability, you only need one more number. Let’s say you that want to know the probability of winning if you bet on number 6. This means that you win if the ball lands on 1 number (6), and you lose if it lands on any of the other 36 numbers.

To get the probability of wining, just put both numbers together: one number to win/37 possible outcomes = 1/37 ≈ 0.027 = 2.7 %. If you look at the table above again, this is the probability of winning a straight-up bet in European or French roulette.

As you can see, the probability of winning is simply the number of ball slots that you bet on, divided by the number of all possible slots that the ball can land on. On the contrary, if you want to know the probability of losing, you divide the number of ball slots that you did not bet on by the number of all possible slots that the ball can land on.

In our case, if the ball lands on any other of the 36 numbers besides the one that you bet on, you lose: 36/37 ≈ 0.9729 = 97.3 %.

If you put both, the probability of winning and the probability of losing, together, you should get 100 % since there is no other possible outcome. You either win or you lose, there is no draw.

2.7 % + 97.3 % = 100 %

En Prison

Ok, now let’s refresh what ‘En Prison’ does: if the ball lands on 0 during your even money bet, your bet stays untouched. If you win the next spin with this same bet you win nothing, but you get your money back.

This description might be a bit confusing when you want to translate it to probability calculation, so let’s simplify it.

Let’s say that you bet on black (it does not matter which even money bet you make; the probability is the same every time). If the ball lands on a black number you win, if it lands on red you lose, and if it lands on 0 you get the chance to keep your money (you neither win nor lose). You only win if the ball lands on black the first time.

There are 18 black numbers and 37 different numbers in total, so the probability of winning with the ‘En Prison’ rule is: 18/37 ≈ 0.486 = 48.6 %

The probability to win is the same as betting on black without the ‘En Prison’ rule.

 

What is the point of this rule then?!

I’m glad you asked! For this rule to make sense, you need to look at what happens if you lose. With or without the rule, you always lose if the ball lands on a red number. It’s the zero that makes a difference. Without the rule, if the ball lands on zero, you lose. But with the rule in play, if the ball lands on zero, you do not necessarily lose!

Let’s calculate the probability of losing your bet. As I said before, you lose if the ball lands on red. That means 18 numbers divided by all 37 numbers = 18/37 ≈ 0.486 = 48.6 %. Now let’s look at the zero.

The probability of the ball landing on 0 is the same as for any other single number (we calculated this in the beginning): 1/37 ≈ 0.027 = 2.7 %. So the ball hit 0 and now, in order for you to lose it must hit a red number again. We already have this: 18/37 ≈ 0.486 = 48.6 %. The probability of you losing if the ball lands on 0 and then on red is 2.7 % × 48.6 % ≈ 0.013 = 1.3 %.

The only thing left to do now is to put all these pessimistic probabilities together: The ball lands on red, or the ball lands on zero and then on red = 48.6 % + 1.3 % = 49.9 %.

Let’s compare this result with the result without the ‘En Prison’ rule in play: 18 red numbers + zero divided by all numbers = (18+1)/37 = 19/37 ≈ 0.513 = 51.3 %. This means that you have more chances of losing without the ‘En Prison’ rule in play.

This is where this rule makes a difference. It does not help you win – but it does help you not lose.

In case you noticed, if you sum up your winning and losing probabilities, you get 48.6 % + 49.9 % = 98.5 % and not 100 %. This is because the ‘En Prison’ rule has the option where neither you nor the casino wins – the probability of this is about 1.5 %.

The payout with the ‘En Prison’ rule does not change because the payout only matters when you win, and your winning odds are the same with or without the rule: 1:1.

La Partage

‘La Partage’ is also a rule that applies to even money bets even money bet. If the ball lands on zero, you get half of your money back. One thing to remember here is that whether you get your money back or not does not have anything to do with your probability to win.

If you bet on black again, you can only win if the ball lands on black, which is 18 out of 37 numbers = 18/37 ≈ 0.486 = 48.6 %.

If the ball lands on red you lose, and if it lands on zero you lose as well (just not as much). Your probability of losing is 18 red numbers + zero, divided by all 37 numbers = (18+1)/37 = 19/37 ≈ 0.513 = 51.3 %.

In terms of probability, the ‘La Partage’ rule does not help you at all compared to ‘En Prison’. But in terms of your money, it helps you just the same.

Bet: 10 $ on black
Payout: 1:1
Ball lands on black (you win): you win 10 $ and now have 20 $
Ball lands on red (you lose): you lose 10 $ and now have 0 $
Ball lands on 0 and then black: you keep the bet and still have 10 $
Ball lands on 0 and then red: you lose 10 $ and now have 0 $

Bet: 10 $ on black
Payout: 1:1
Ball lands on black (you win): you win 10 $ and now have 20 $
Ball lands on red (you lose): you lose 10 $ and now have 0 $
Ball lands on 0 and then black: you keep half the bet and now have 5 $
Ball lands on 0 and then red: you keep half the bet and now have 5 $

You can see that the only difference between these rules is what happens in the case of the ball landing on zero. But if you average out both possible outcomes of zero, you end up with $5 in the case where either of these rules applies.

Best Roulette Strategies

To be honest, I never used any of the most popular roulette strategies described below, and I will tell you why in a moment. Roulette has countless different strategies, but several gained more popularity. Here they are:

I tested 6 most popular strategies a million times!

Read about what I found out and which strategy turned out to be the best!

Read more

The Martingale Strategy

This strategy relies on even money bets. It doubles your bet each time you lose and resets your bet back to the initial bet once you win.

The idea is to cover all losses by doubling your bet every time you lose, and to minimize risk by resetting your bet to initial bet once you win.

In theory, this can work if you have a loaded, bottomless wallet – otherwise, you are going to lose all your money very quickly. The problem is that no matter what you do, your odds of winning each round are still under 50 %, which makes you lose in the long run.

Don’t get me wrong, you can get lucky and succeed with this strategy, but that will be because of your luck – not because of the strategy. 🙂

The D’Alembert Strategy

Like the Martingale strategy, the D’Alembert strategy relies on even money bets and increases your bet when you lose and decreases it when you win.

But unlike the Martingale, it does not double your bets or cut them down to the initial bet value; it simply increases or decreases the bet for 1 unit.

For example: The value of your initial bet is, say $3, and the value of the increase/decrease is $1. This means that if you lose 2 times in a row after the initial bet, you go from $3 to $4 to $5 bet. If you win, you go from $5 to $4, and so on.

The idea of the D’Alembert strategy is basically the same as the Martingale, except it does not escalate your bets so drastically. The D’Alembert strategy would suit you much better if you are someone who does not have millions at your disposal, but in the end this strategy also crashes head first into the same wall as the Martingale. Both of these theories would work wonderfully if your even money bets had 50% chance or more. But the casino always has the edge, so in the long run you would lose with the D’Alembert strategy as well, just slowly – unless you are very lucky again.

The Fibonacci Strategy

The Fibonacci strategy again works in a similar way the Martingale and D’Alembert strategies do, using even money bets to increase or decrease your bet when you lose or win.

The Fibonacci strategy uses the Fibonacci sequence where each number is the sum of the previous two: 1 1 2 3 5 8 13 21 34 …

You start at the beginning of the sequence with $1 as your bet. When you lose, you move one up the sequence. If you win, you move 2 back down.

It works just like the D’Alembert, strategy except that your bet values, increases or decreases are pre-defined by the sequence, while with the D’Alembert strategy you are free to choose the values yourself.

These were three examples of some of the most popular progressive roulette strategies. Along the way I sort of already answered why I do not use them. Although they can be really fun to implement, they are just a way of playing and in no way do they increase your odds. Casino’s house edge is sadly something that will always be on the casino’s side. All you can do is hope that luck stays on your side.

However, I must add that if you are not sure how to bet at roulette, it is still much better to use one of these strategies than to just go around placing your chips randomly where they may fall.

Hot or Cold Numbers

This is a common roulette question that has been going around for as long as roulette has existed (which is about 300 years, I think).

Let’s take the red/black bet as an example again. The idea is that if a black number was played a certain amount of times in a row, then a red number must be due. This is an interesting way in which our mind plays a trick on us.

What you must know is that every time the roulette wheel is spun, the ball always has an equal chance of falling on any of the 37 numbers. So if the first number is black, the next number has the exact same chance of being black. Or red, for that matter.

Unfortunately, there are no hot or cold numbers. Every spin is independent of the previous one.

What Is the Best Roulette Strategy?

Once you sit down at a roulette table, there is no strategy that can improve your odds. If you want your odds to be the best, the only thing you can do is choose the right roulette table before you start playing.

Remember, European and French roulette have a better house edge than American roulette, and 2 additional rules can help you with playing even money bets at French roulette.

My advice is to stick to French roulette for even money bets or stick to either European or French roulette for all other kinds of bets. Alternatively, you can choose a roulette game derived from one of the two if you want to spice up your game a bit.
